commit_message:
galera: make gcache recovery configurable

On startup, mariadb 10.5 now reloads previous writesets cached on
disk to serve IST to other joiner nodes instead of SST.

This cache on disk is unreliable, so make this feature configurable
and disable it by default (as it was in mariadb 10.3).

Change-Id: I176ac88f9d91080926556690319941bd18bd34f6
Closes-Bug: #1984264
(cherry picked from commit 8556df09e0830e73db102779a7c9655c9a895b03)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-tripleo refs/changes/22/858622/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # [*gcache_recover*] # (optional) Recover gcache on galera startup. # Defaults to false # $gcache_recover = false, $gcache_size_opt = "gcache.size=${gcache_size};" } else { $gcache_size_opt = '' } $gcache_recover_opt = "gcache.recover=${$gcache_recover ? { false => 'no', default => 'yes' }};" $gcache_options = "${gcache_size_opt}${gcache_recover_opt}"

commit_message:
Add spec for rfc2317 behavior

Related-bug: #1918424
Change-Id: Idcfb63a5ae6eb01a8cc3b49e547ba977df234a92
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/00/791400/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =================================================== RFC 2317 support in Neutron with designate provider =================================================== RFE: https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1918424 The creation of PTR DNS zones for non byte-delimited subnets is not possible in OpenStack, it is therefore impossible to manage PTR records in case of a classless in-addr delegation, as described in RFC 2317 [1]_. This spec describes the addition of options to customize the format of PTR fields globally or per ``IPAllocationPool``. Problem Description =================== One can be given a delegation of a reverse zone with an unusual name, for instance ``0-25.2.0.192.in-addr.arpa`` (when assigned the ``192.0.2.0/25`` prefix). This scheme is based on the fact that a DNS record for reverse resolution can be a CNAME to another record. This spec adds a generic mechanism to properly handle such cases, as handling them is not currently possible. This specification does not deal with the "provider" part, i.e. the addition of CNAMEs and NS in the parent zone, which has no reason to be managed by Designate / Neutron. Proposed Change =============== Add a ``ipv4_ptr_zone`` setting to define a PTR zone name, and a ``ipv4_ptr_record_template`` setting to define the record name template. The template can use placeholders which are replaced with the n-th byte or nibble of the IP address. ``%s(octetN)s`` is a candidate and is already a notation used in Designate [2]_. #### Usage example Configuration for subnet 192.0.2.0/25 would be as follow: :: ipv4_ptr_zone = "0-25.2.0.192.in-addr.arpa" ipv4_ptr_record_template = "%(octet3)s" Which would lead to this zone file: :: $ORIGIN 0-25.2.0.192.in-addr.arpa 1 IN PTR reverse-1.example. 2 IN PTR reverse-2.example. # [...] 127 IN PTR reverse-127.example. When absent, the old behavior of ``ipv4_ptr_zone_prefix_size`` or ``ipv6_ptr_zone_prefix_size`` is kept. ### First step: global Neutron configuration The behavior described above would be configured with settings in the global neutron configuration file. Raise an error in case of invalid setting configuration: * ``ipv4_ptr_zone_prefix_size`` is set and either ``ipv4_ptr_zone`` or ``ipv4_ptr_record_template`` is set. * ``ipv4_ptr_zone`` is set and ``ipv4_ptr_record_template`` is not set. * ``ipv4_ptr_zone`` is not set and ``ipv4_ptr_record_template`` is set. * The same applies for IPv6 settings. ### Second step: per-IPAllocationPool configuration Global settings could be overwritten for each ``IPAllocationPool``; however, it would require an update of both ``IPAllocationPool`` and ``IPAllocation`` models (in ``neutron/db/models_v2.py``), as ``IPAllocation`` would need to keep track of ``IPAllocationPool`` rDNS settings. Theses settings could be stored in the ``IPAllocationPool`` model: :: class IPAllocationPool(model_base.BASEV2, model_base.HasId): # [snip] ptr_zone = sa.Column(sa.String(255), nullable=True) ptr_record_template = sa.Column(sa.String(255), nullable=True) A reference to the originating ``IPAllocationPool`` could be kept into the ``IPAllocation`` model in order to retrieve the rDNS settings: :: class IPAllocation(model_base.BASEV2): # [snip] ip_allocation_pool_id = sa.Column(sa.String(64), nullable=False) Models Impact ------------- Add optional ``ptr_zone`` and ``ptr_record_template`` fields in ``IPAllocationPool`` model, and ``ip_allocation_pool_id`` in ``IPAllocation`` to be able to get the values of ``ptr_zone`` and ``ptr_record_template``. User use cases -------------- This specification addresses the specific case where the entity managing a non-octet boundary subnet is distinct from the entity delegating it, and therefore they cannot share the same rDNS zone. A typical use case would be a company to which a provider supplies a /25 IPv4. The company, if it wants to manage its rDNS, would then have no other solution than the described behavior. Testing ------- * Unit tests. Assignee(s) ----------- * Charles Decoux <charles@cri.epita.fr> References ========== .. [1] https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc2317 .. [2] https://github.com/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_designate/blob/stable/victoria/templates/designate.conf.j2#L400

commit_message:
Add spec for DNS subdomain support in OVN

Related-Bug: #1960850
Change-Id: I785683007ecabedadcf265c59941192b84b447ae
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/58/832658/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ==================================== Example Spec - The title of your RFE ==================================== Include the URL of your launchpad RFE: https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1960850 Right now, we set a single domain name per deployment, stated in the neutron configuration file. However, there are use cases where it is useful to provide more granularity to DNS, like at a network or port level where the dns_domain attribute exists. This is something that would not require any extensions when using the OVN driver. This proposal suggests supporting DNS subdomains at a network level just in the ml2/OVN driver. Problem Description =================== Having subdomains would allow users to reuse the names of their instances among different and separated networks (And therefore, different projects). Since we do allow having different servers with the same name on a deployment, it makes sense to have a resource to allow some differentiation when they need to use the internal DNS service for those instances. An full example is given on the RFE description There are several use cases for this: * In a multitenant environment, different users working on different projects use common hostnames for their VMs, which leads to a FQDN conflict. Users dont have know the hostnames other VMs have, so they could generate an unexpected FQDN clash. * In a multitenant environment, users working in an application with different stages might want to re-use hostnames and make a distinction on the subdomain. Example: app001.uat.example.com (for UAT) vs app001.prd.example.com (for Production) both have the same hostname. Proposed Change =============== The proposal is to not change the default behaviour of DNS in OVN, but rather extending it with a boolean configuration option that would define whether the deployment needs to use network names as subdomain or not. If this option is set to True, then the subdomain would always be added from the name of the network. We can do that because the DNS table in OVN makes an association at a port level - DNS records are grouped per neutron network and stored as a pair of IP address - FQDN. See more about OVN DNS tables in the documentation [0]) Example of how we would like to change the DB entry: Network name: net1 Network ID: 142f7e6a-776d-4e88-b512-3a06185d2362 Network subnet range: 192.168.101.0/24 Domain name: dnsdomain.com The resulting OVN Northbound DB entry after the change would be: :: _uuid : 4496fb0c-52f5-462d-bf2b-be64df15c0c1 external_ids : {ls_name=neutron-142f7e6a-776d-4e88-b512-3a06185d2362} records : {"238.101.168.192.in-addr.arpa"=server.net1.dnsdomain.com, server="192.168.101.238", server.net1.dnsdomain.com="192.168.101.238"} In the port that is assigned to the server: :: dns_assignment | fqdn='server2.mydns.conf.', hostname='server2', ip_address='192.168.101.238' References ========== [0] https://www.ovn.org/support/dist-docs/ovn-nb.5.html

commit_message:
Add flows tables for distributed metadata datapath

Add tables based on the spec:
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron-specs/+/802854/9/specs/yoga/distributed-metadata-data-path.rst

METADATA_EGRESS_NAT = 80
METADATA_EGRESS_OUTPUT = 87
METADATA_IP_ARP_RESPONDER = 90
METADATA_INGRESS_DIRECT = 91

Partially-Implements: blueprint distributed-metadata-datapath
Change-Id: Iec4249f0c2a735dfc6e1f826c71b57d1a6351768

it work with docker. Any upcoming Kubernetes version bump will be
ignored for this particular gate, and it will be removed when Kubernetes

commit_message:
Pin docker gate to Kubernetes 1.23

1.23 version of Kubernetes is the last one, which supports
dockershim[1], therefore it needs to be pinned to that version to make
it work with docker. Any upcoming Kubernetes version bump will be
ignored for this particular gate, and it will be removed when Kubernetes
makes it EOL[2].
